narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course explored the physics of semiconductors and their various properties.
Semiconductor physics, material science
Conceptual Quantum Mechanics, transistor physics

I learned about the mechanics of semiconductor technology. I learned how to draw and understand energy band diagrams for homojunctions and heterojunctions. I learned how charge carriers move through pn junctions. Furthermore, I learned how to integrate pn junctions into devices such as JFETs, MOSFETs, and BJTs. I gained insight into how these devices are relevant today in semiconductor industry.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course didn't translate very well to being taught virtually. The cancellation of the lab made it hard to understand how the concepts we were taught in class were applicable. The slides were very confusing, and I feel that the material moved too fast. The textbook was also very confusing.

Strengths: lectures lined up really closely with the textbook and had a lot of content overlap, so it made the textbook extremely useful. Professor Tang also was very knowledgeable and was available to answer questions. Exams were more concept, rather than math heavy, which made the course much easier to manage

Weaknesses: grading wasnt very timely, so it was hard to gauge how you were doing in the class. Review sessions for exams were sometimes scheduled last minute and without student feedback on a time that worked.

I would have liked to have all of the classes recorded. Personally, zoom lecture could be a struggle to follow along with and I felt I could better understand the material when I am able to pause and stop the lecture to digest what was covered.
lectures were done well, perhaps there could have been some better communication with the TA(s)

The course was well taught. The professor was willing and encouraging of questions. He took time to answer any gaps of understanding. I would have liked the lectures slides to have more text to accompany the pictures. This would help to guide studying after class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish that the course had not used very many slides, and had instead been written on some virtual whiteboard. I feel like seeing the derivations and equations being derived would make them easier to understandable instead of just seeing them plastered on a slide all at once.

Recorded lectures would be nice because it is a very complex and high level topic. Plus there were no defined office hours, you have to email to meet with the professor or TA, which can sometimes discourage students from reaching out to ask questions. Lectures slides also had very little info on them besides graphics, so the slides were not helpful at all while studying
I thought this course did great making accommodations for the students.
more communication with TA(s)
The course used live lectures, this allowed for direct contact with the professor. There were also opportunities to meet with TAs. This created a more flexible schedule to go over material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would not recommend this course unless it is required for the major. The presentation of the material was very confusing.

Yes, but only if you are interested in the physics of semiconductor devices and you're willing to put in the time to study the textbook. A lot of the content requires that you develop some intuition about how current flows through semiconductors, properties of junctions, etc. Simply attending the lectures may not be enough to get a good grasp of these topics. Hence you might need to follow along by reading the textbook on your own.
If its something that youre interested in, sure! Hong tang is a good and kind professor. Really only take it if its for a requirement of a major, this wouldnt be just a casual STEM class to take.

I would recommend this course to another student. It was a comprehensive introductory class on semiconductors. I have a strong foundation to take other classes in the field and learn more about the subject.
